knowledge_base.description: Complete operational guide for WAFR - how to prepare, conduct, and improve reviews
knowledge_base.key_insight: This is the COMPLETE operational playbook for WAFR - combining AWS workshop, EB Khiyami's best practices, and official framework structure

executive_summary.what: Step-by-step guide for running WAFR reviews across 3 phases: Prepare → Review → Improve
executive_summary.why_critical_for_agents: Your Discovery Agent needs to follow AWS's best practices for conducting reviews - not just ask questions, but create the right environment and approach

3_phases.prepare: Define workload, scope, people, culture, documentation
3_phases.review: Conduct the actual assessment with 11 best practices

key_principles: WAFR is not an audit - it's about architectural health
Create a safe space - no blame culture
Maybe == No (capture current state, not intended state)

eb_khiyami_definition.author: Ebrahim (EB) Khiyami, Senior Solutions Architect, AWS Well-Architected Specialist
eb_khiyami_definition.what_is_wafr: The consistent process of LEARNING AWS best practices, MEASURING architecture against these best practices, identifying architecture risks and creating an IMPROVEMENT plan to address them
eb_khiyami_definition.analogy: Building a technology system is not different from building any other product. There are practices and codes to follow to ensure alignment with industry standards.
eb_khiyami_definition.mechanisms: You need mechanisms to ensure teams are AWARE of practices and FOLLOWING them
eb_khiyami_definition.goal: The ultimate goal is to IMPROVE your systems' architectures so they can better support business needs

aws_wellarchitected_framework.analogy: Creating a software system is a lot like constructing a building. If the foundation is not solid, structural problems can undermine the integrity and function of the building.
aws_wellarchitected_framework.importance: When architecting technology solutions, if you neglect the six pillars, it can become challenging to build a system that delivers on your expectations and requirements.
aws_wellarchitected_framework.benefit: Incorporating these pillars into your architecture will help you produce stable and efficient systems. This allows you to focus on other aspects of design, such as functional requirements.

pillar_1.name: Operational Excellence
pillar_1.focus: Run and monitor systems, continually improve processes and procedures
pillar_1.business_value: Provides insight into system status, enables effective operation and event response, supports continuous improvement

pillar_2.name: Security
pillar_2.focus: Protect data, systems, and assets; control access; respond to security events
pillar_2.business_value: Protects your data and systems, controls access, responds automatically to security events

pillar_3.name: Reliability
pillar_3.focus: Ensure workload performs its intended function correctly and consistently
pillar_3.business_value: Strong foundations, resilient architecture, consistent change management, proven failure recovery processes

pillar_4.name: Performance Efficiency
pillar_4.focus: Use computing resources efficiently to meet requirements and maintain efficiency as demand changes
pillar_4.business_value: Delivers sustained performance over time, adapts to changing requirements

pillar_5.name: Cost Optimization
pillar_5.focus: Run systems to deliver business value at the lowest price point
pillar_5.business_value: In-depth guidance for building capability, designing workload, selecting services, configuring and operating services, applying cost optimization techniques

pillar_6.name: Sustainability
pillar_6.focus: Minimize environmental impacts of running cloud workloads
pillar_6.business_value: Design principles, operational guidance, best practices, potential trade-offs, and improvement plans for sustainability targets

aws_wellarchitected_framework.order_of_review: Recommended to follow the order: Operational Excellence → Security → Reliability → Performance Efficiency → Cost Optimization → Sustainability
aws_wellarchitected_framework.note_on_order: However, your organization's priority might be different. You can choose to review specific pillars based on business needs.

phase_1_prepare.overview: Before running WAFR, invest time in understanding and documenting workload components. This saves time during review when more people are involved.

eb_khiyami_best_practices.preparation_timeline: Preparation typically starts about 3 weeks before actual review date
depends_on: Priority given to complete review by organization

step_1.name: Define a workload
step_1.description: A workload is a set of components (technology, people, processes) that delivers business value to your organization
step_1.level: The level of business and technology that leaders communicate about
step_1.example: A website where customers place and track orders, along with infrastructure and processes that support its back-end

step_2.name: Define core team (sponsors)
step_2.importance: Key component to successful WAFR is engaging the right people from beginning

workload_sponsor.definition: Person (or team) ultimately responsible for success (or failure) of workload
workload_sponsor.authority: Should have right level of authority to influence and take actions to address risks
workload_sponsor.critical: This is the Single Threaded Owner (STO)

variations: One person responsible for multiple pillars
Multiple teams responsible for one pillar
pillar_sponsors.goal: Ensure right person to answer review questions for each pillar AND address risks later

examples.reliability_pillar: May need SMEs on: database, networking, security, operations
examples.operational_excellence_pillar: May need: Enterprise Architects, Application Development, business/finance

step_3.name: Decide on the pillars and lenses
step_3.ideal: Get comprehensive look at workload from all six pillars perspective
step_3.pragmatic: May need to focus only on specific pillars based on priorities
step_3.example: If you changed security practice, you may review only Security Pillar
step_3.recommended_order: Follow pillars order as listed: Operational Excellence → Security → Reliability → Performance Efficiency → Cost Optimization → Sustainability
step_3.flexibility: Your organization's priority might be different - decide on order based on needs

lenses.definition: Lenses extend guidance to specific industry and technology domains

step_4.name: Decide on session's type

full_day_review.duration: One full day for all six pillars
pros: Helps uncover improvement opportunities the most

multiple_sessions.duration: Several sessions over several days for selected pillars
cons: May require extra work to update different teams on different milestones

step_4.communication_is_key: Communication across teams during review is crucial - helps answer questions and uncover issues collectively

live_vs_async.not_recommended: Asynchronously (teams answering questions in WA Tool separately and sharing later)
live_vs_async.reason: Live sessions enable real-time collaboration and discussion

step_5.name: Collect the necessary data for the review
what_to_collect: Documents explaining main components of system
Teams responsible for operating the workload

for_complex_workloads.integration: Use Trusted Advisor actions to understand compliance with best practices and incorporate into review
for_complex_workloads.example: How to use AWS Well Architected with AWS Trusted Advisor for data-driven cost optimization

step_1.name: Define: Workload and Scope

workload_definition.official: A workload identifies a set of components that together deliver business value. The workload is usually the level of detail that business and technology leaders communicate about.
workload_definition.complexity: Workloads vary from static websites to architectures with multiple data stores and many components

q1.question: Who owns the workload?
q1.details: Who's responsible if disruption of the workload impacts the business?

q2.question: What is the purpose of the workload?

q3.question: Does this workload need to exist?
q3.test: What happens if you shut it down?

group_discussion_questions.q4: Is the workload customer facing or internal?
group_discussion_questions.q5: Is the workload production or non-production?
group_discussion_questions.q6: What phase is the workload in its lifecycle?
group_discussion_questions.q7: What is the impact if the workload had a disruption?
group_discussion_questions.q8: What are the boundaries of the workload?
group_discussion_questions.q9: What other workloads depend on this workload to function?
group_discussion_questions.q10: What dependencies does this workload have?

step_1.requirement: If you cannot clearly answer most of these questions, address this before continuing with WAFR

choosing_workload.context: Large organizations have thousands of workloads
choosing_workload.priority: Workloads critical to business (if they went offline, business would stop existing)
choosing_workload.culture: Implementing continuous improvement and consistent WAFRs across teams is crucial

scope_definition.ideal: Run full WAFR across all six pillars to identify trade-offs and understand context
scope_definition.pragmatic: Focusing on specific prioritized pillar(s) or area is a good way to start
scope_definition.rationale: Time is valuable - delivering well-defined slice of larger review with actionable results delivers more value
scope_definition.iteration: Iterate and expand scope over time

learning_objectives: Answered questions to understand the workload better
Defined boundaries and dependencies to keep WAFR in scope

step_2.name: Discuss: People and Culture

sto_definition.accountability_question: Who is responsible if the workload no longer functions as intended?

sto_critical_importance.without_sto: Running WAFR without STO results in poor outcomes
consequences: Improvement items won't get prioritized in product roadmap
Unachievable list of backlog items that never get acted on
sto_critical_importance.sto_must_own: The STO must own the WAFR and be invested in the process

discussion_questions: Who needs to be present to answer each category of questions?
Which stakeholders are required during which parts of WAFR?
How can you inform different stakeholders of questions in advance?

pillar_sponsors.benefit: Can accelerate and increase value of WAFR process
responsibilities: Attend specific parts of WAFR to provide information or guidance
Own the outcomes for their subject matter area
Define, influence and communicate strategic cross-organizational changes

cloud_center_of_excellence.question: Does your organization have a Cloud Center of Excellence or Cloud Community of Practice?
cloud_center_of_excellence.recommendation: Start small and grow a group of like-minded people for architectural health discussions

create_safe_space.culture_importance: Developing healthy organizational culture is crucial for productive technology discussions
create_safe_space.risk: If people feel their homework is being marked, they become defensive and productive conversations shut down

positive_intent.requirement: Set positive intent from beginning and re-emphasize throughout
positive_intent.reality: Those who built the workload did the best they could with resources and knowledge available at the time
positive_intent.frame: WAFR must be framed as opportunity to discover improvements

not_an_audit.what_wafr_is_not: A WAFR is NOT an audit
not_an_audit.compliance: Although findings can help meet compliance standards, it's not there to score your workload

two_key_questions.where_are_we: WAFR is a chance to ask 'Where are we?' and capture point-in-time view
two_key_questions.where_should_we_go: Use findings to make informed decision to answer 'Where should we go?'

create_safe_space.journey: Architectural improvement is a journey AWS Well-Architected can guide you on

practice_exercise.activity: Work as group and practice communicating positive intent
questions: Why are you running the WAFR?
What do you hope to get out of it?
How will the experience benefit everyone?
Where are you now, and where do you want to get to?

learning_objectives: Defined Single Threaded Owner (STO) to own workload, WAFR and improvements
Defined which people and teams can help answering WAFR questions
Defined pillar champions who can provide SME guidance in specialism area
Reinforced positive intent focusing on architectural health and optimization
Discussed where you are and where you hope to go with workload

step_3.name: Discover: Documentation and Infrastructure
step_3.purpose: Gather documentation and understand infrastructure before review

step_4.name: Create: Workload in WA Tool
step_4.purpose: Create workload in AWS WA Tool programmatically or via console
step_4.importance: Essential for capturing and tracking review results

phase_2_review.overview: Now that preparation is complete, it's time to run the WAFR with tips and tricks for efficiency

pre_wafr.before_group_discussion: Go over tips and tricks together
pre_wafr.rules_of_engagement: Discuss at start, agree on approach, get consensus

questions: Who will be sharing their screen and what will they be sharing?
Who will be taking notes in WA Tool or another format?
Which pillars will you be reviewing and in which order?
Do you have the right people in the room to answer questions?
How will you capture out of scope items and parking lot them?
How much time allocated for each section/pillar review?
What do you want to achieve in the time allocated?

11_review_tips.overview: Plan meeting(s) focused on capturing data points about workload architectural choices

tip_1.name: Communicate Positive Intent
tip_1.details: Revisit positive intent with participants. Those present may feel threatened by having work questioned, so reaffirm WAFR is purely to find improvement opportunities and reinforce no blame culture.
tip_1.risk: If people are defensive you will not capture required data points, leading to poor outcomes
tip_1.for_discovery_agent: Start every assessment by explicitly stating this is not an audit, it's about discovering improvements

tip_2.name: Bring a Supporter
tip_2.details: Navigating complex architecture, asking questions, moderating responses and taking notes is challenging for one person.
tip_2.team_sport: Successful WAFR is a team sport
tip_2.roles: Having someone to alternate roles allows one person to run review while other takes notes, checks documentation, monitors chat
tip_2.for_discovery_agent: In automated platform, agents handle these roles (Orchestrator + Discovery + Assessment)

tip_3.name: Stay On Topic
tip_3.details: Easy to get off topic when having group conversations around architectural decisions.
tip_3.time_efficiency: To be efficient with time, hold each other accountable to stay on topic
tip_3.parking_lot: Use parking lot area to capture concepts and ideas for future discussion
tip_3.for_discovery_agent: If client goes off topic, acknowledge but redirect: 'That's important - let me note that for later discussion. For this question...'

tip_4.name: Take Good Notes
tip_4.details: Simply ticking boxes in WA Tool provides no context to someone revisiting WAFR in later milestones.
tip_4.best_practice: Use notes box or external document linked from WAFR notes if you exceed character limit
tip_4.for_discovery_agent: Every answer should include context - not just 'yes/no' but 'yes because...' or 'no because...'

tip_5.name: No Solutioning
tip_5.details: Focus on capturing data points about workload, don't get drawn into solutioning.
problems: Eats up lot of time during session
Won't have all data points to make best decisions
Not best use of other participants' time
tip_5.for_discovery_agent: If client asks 'What should we do?', defer: 'We'll provide recommendations after completing assessment. For now, let's understand current state.'

tip_6.name: Focus on the Workload, Not the Tool
tip_6.details: Common to share screen showing WA Tool in AWS Console. Although capturing data in tool is crucial, don't get too caught up with it.
tip_6.priority: Focus energy on having discussion about architecture
tip_6.conversational: Keep review conversational and paraphrase questions to align with context
tip_6.for_discovery_agent: Your conversational approach is perfect - don't show WA Tool UI, just have natural dialogue

tip_7.name: Slice It Up
tip_7.details: Do you need to do all six pillars in one sitting?
tip_7.recommendation: Spread review out in smaller sessions
benefits: Easier to schedule with desired participants
tip_7.for_discovery_agent: Offer to focus on specific pillars first: 'Would you like to start with Security and Reliability, or review all pillars?'

tip_8.name: Take Breaks
tip_8.details: Reviewing architecture thoroughly is tiring for participants, concentration lapses over time.
tip_8.best_practice: Take control of WAFR with frequent scheduled breaks
tip_8.time_respect: Be frugal with participants' time - suggest people drop out when no longer required. Time is money.
tip_8.for_discovery_agent: In automated platform, users can pause/resume. Remind them: 'Feel free to take a break and resume later.'

tip_9.name: Maybe == No
tip_9.details: If answer for question is 'maybe', 'kind of', or 'we have something in backlog to address that', then answer is 'No'.
tip_9.key_principle: WAFR is about capturing honest current state of workload, not intended state
tip_9.for_discovery_agent: CRITICAL: If client says 'we're planning to...', 'we have a ticket for...', 'it's on our roadmap...', mark as NO. Explain: 'For WAFR, we assess current state. We'll note your planned improvements separately.'

tip_10.name: Trade Offs
tip_10.details: Being Well-Architected is about making trade offs between pillars.
tip_10.example: To make workload more resilient will probably cost you more money
tip_10.purpose: Pillars provide structure for conversations and help make informed architectural choices
tip_10.for_discovery_agent: When identifying gaps, acknowledge trade-offs: 'Improving reliability here may increase costs. That's normal - it's about making informed trade-offs.'

tip_11.name: Perfection is an Illusion
tip_11.details: Don't let perfection be the enemy of good.
tip_11.reality: Workloads are rarely perfect, and often do not need to be
tip_11.avoid: Turning this into exercise of 'Gold Plating' everything
tip_11.focus: Make workload function safely and efficiently for its intended business purpose
tip_11.for_discovery_agent: Reassure clients: 'No workload is perfect. We're finding opportunities to improve what matters most for your business.'

opening.example: Welcome! This Well-Architected review is about discovering opportunities to improve your architecture. This is not an audit - we're here to help you understand where you are and where you could go. Let's start by understanding your workload.

discovery_10_questions.example_q1: Who owns this workload? Specifically, who's responsible if it stops delivering business value?
discovery_10_questions.example_q7: What would be the business impact if this workload had a disruption? Would the business stop, or is it more of an inconvenience?

assessment_apply_maybe_no.assessment_agent: For each WAFR question, applies 'Maybe == No' rule
assessment_apply_maybe_no.client_says: We're planning to implement backups next quarter.
assessment_apply_maybe_no.agent_response: Thanks for sharing that plan. For this assessment, we evaluate what's implemented today. I'll mark backups as 'not implemented' but note your Q1 plan in the improvement roadmap.

handling_tangents.client_goes_off_topic: ...and that reminds me, we're also thinking about migrating to containers...
handling_tangents.discovery_agent_response: That's an interesting direction! Let me note that as a potential future topic. For this current question about data backup, can you tell me...

closing.example: We've identified 12 opportunities to improve your architecture. Remember, no workload is perfect. These recommendations will help you make informed trade-offs between cost, performance, and reliability.

sample_conversation.orchestrator_opening: Welcome! I'm here to help you conduct a Well-Architected review of your e-commerce platform. This is not an audit - we're discovering opportunities to improve your architecture. Let's start by understanding your workload. This will take about 15-20 minutes. Sound good?
sample_conversation.discovery_q1: Let's start with ownership. Who owns this e-commerce platform? Specifically, who's accountable if the platform goes down and revenue stops?
sample_conversation.client_answer_1: That would be our VP of Engineering, Sarah.
sample_conversation.discovery_q2: Perfect. And what's the primary purpose of this workload?
sample_conversation.client_answer_2: It serves our external customers - they use it to browse products and make purchases.
sample_conversation.discovery_q3: Got it. What would happen if we shut this platform down?
sample_conversation.client_answer_3: The business would stop completely. We're 100% online - no physical stores.
sample_conversation.discovery_notes: Owner: VP Eng (Sarah). Purpose: External customers, e-commerce. Impact if down: Business stops (critical workload).
sample_conversation.discovery_q7: What phase is this workload in?
sample_conversation.client_answer_7: It's been in production for 3 years, but we're actively developing new features.
sample_conversation.discovery_q8: Can you describe the boundaries? What's included in 'the e-commerce platform' vs. what's separate?
sample_conversation.client_answer_8: Includes the website, product catalog, shopping cart, checkout, and payment processing. Excludes our warehouse management system and customer support system.
sample_conversation.assessment_q_security: For security, do you have backups configured for your database?
sample_conversation.client_answer_security: We're planning to implement automated backups next quarter. Right now we have manual backups running weekly.
sample_conversation.assessment_agent_applies_maybe_no: Thanks for sharing your plan. For this assessment, we need to evaluate what's implemented today. I'll mark automated backups as 'not implemented' but note your Q1 automation plan. For now, you have manual weekly backups - is that correct?
sample_conversation.assessment_notes: Backups: Manual weekly (not automated). Planned: Automate Q1. Mark as NO for automated, YES for backups exist.
sample_conversation.report_closing: We've completed the assessment! I've identified 12 opportunities to improve your e-commerce platform across the 6 pillars. The good news: your platform is serving customers well. These recommendations will help you make informed decisions about trade-offs between cost, reliability, and performance. No workload is perfect - let's focus on what matters most for your business.
